tmp: The information and predicted resaults are for reference only. Seek professional medical assistance if you need it.

card1.title: What is Melanoma?
content: Melanoma is a kind of skin cancer. Although Melanoma only accounts for 1-2% of skin cancer cases, it is easily the most deadly type of skin cancer.
It can grow rapidly over weeks or months and it may spread to other parts of the body and potentially become fatal.

According to the American Cancer Society, melanoma has on average a 94% 5-year relative survival rate. For reference, the most common type of skin cancer, Basal Cell Carcinoma, has a 100% 5-year relative survival rate.

card2.title: Statistics about Melanoma
content: Melanoma is among one of the most common cancers in young people under 30 years old, especially in young women (#3 most diagnosed cancer among ages 25 to 39 in the United States).

Despite Melanoma's deadliness, it is highly curable if caught early. By spreading awareness of the symptoms of Melanoma, more cases of Melanoma can be spotted in early stages when it can be easily treated.
The American Cancer Society’s estimates for melanoma in the United States for 2024 are:
About 100,640 new melanomas will be diagnosed (about 59,170 in men and 41,470 in women)
About 8,290 people are expected to die of melanoma (about 5,430 men and 2,860 women).

card3.title: Signs of Melanoma
content: The most important sign of potential Melanoma is a new spot on the skin or a spot that is changing in size, shape or color.
A spot that looks different from all of the other spots on the skin could also be an important sign.
One of the key rules to be on the lookout for early signs of Melanoma is called The ABCDE rule, it helps us by examining spots or moles and determining whether it is a sign of Melanoma or not.

A. Asymmetry: 
One half of a hole or birthmark does not match the other.

B. Border: 
The edges are irregular, ragged, notched, or blurred.

C. Color: 
The color is not the same all over and may include different shades of brown or black, or sometimes with patches of pink, red, white or blue.

D. Diameter: 
The spot is larger than 6 millimeters across (about 1/4 inch or the size of a pencil eraser), although Melanomas can sometimes be smaller than this.

E. Evolving: 
The mole is changing in size, shape, or color.

card4.title: Risk factors
content: A risk factor is anything that raises your risk of getting a disease such as cancer. Risk factors include a variety of things such as personal lifestyle, age or family history.The major risk factors of Melanoma are as follows:
1. UV Light Exposure
2. Moles
3. History of Melanoma
4. Weakened Immune System
5. Being Older

about: The model is based on Mobile-ViT
You can get source code and other informations on GitHub

diagnosis.title: What's your assigned sex at birth?
What's your current age?
What best describes your race?
Do you have any first degree family history of Melanoma diagnosis?
Do you have any prior personal history of Melanoma diagnosis?
How would you describe your skin?
How would you describe the color of your hair?
choices: Hint of red (including strawberry blond or auburn)

diagnosis.title: Do you have any noticeable moles present since birth?
How would you describe the tone of your skin?
Have you experienced any Sunburns during 0-13 year old?
Do you experience frequent Sunburns in your daily life?
choices: More than one time in the past 12 months

diagnosis.title: Do you have a weakened immune system as a result of certain diseases or medical treatments?
Do you have more than 50 moles on your body currently?
Would you describe yourself as an individual with many freckles?
Are you aware of any genetic skin disorders present in your family?
For the following questions, pick a mole on your body that fits the most of the following description.
Asymmetry: The mole is asymmetrical.
Border: The mole has a ragged or poorly defined border.
Color: The mole has more than one color that differs between areas.
Diameter: The widest part of the mole have a diameter greater than 6mm
Evolving: The mole looks different from the rest or is changing in size, shape, or color.
Where is the mole located?
choices: Areas regularly exposed to the sun (such as Face, Neck or Arms)
Areas uncommonly exposed to the sun (such as Palm, Soles of the Feet, Groin, Beneath the nail or Inside the mouth)

diagnosis.title: Is the mole a newly emerged mole?

scanner.title:
⚠️Read this first⚠️
How to use the scanner?
scanner.content1: Make sure the mole is in the center of the photo and take the photo in good light. If possible, use a macro lens to make the picture as clear as possible.
scanner.title2: 2. Pick a mole on your body that fits the most of the following criteria:
scanner.content2-1:
Asymmetry:
The mole is Asymmetric, one half of the mole looks different from the other half of the mole.
scanner.content2-2:
Border:
The mole is defined by a ragged border.
scanner.content2-3:
Color:
The mole is have more than one color within it's border.
scanner.content2-4:
Diameter:
The mole have a diameter larger than 6mm (0.24 inch or around the diameter of a typical pencil) at it's widest point.
scanner.content2-5:
Evolving:
The mole changes in color, shape or size from time to time
scanner.content3: We provide many models to choose from, please adjust according to your needs.
